title: In Vitro and In Silico Characterization of Novel Fluorobenzhydrazide Deriva-tives With Antibacterial Potential
authors: Sara Janowska; Rafał Kurczab; Sylwia Andrzejczuk; Urszula Kosikowska; Anna Błażewicz; M Janowski; J. Stefanska; Serhii Holota; Roman Lesyk; Monika Wujec
abstract: The search for new compounds with antibacterial activity is of critical importance in modern medicine. The rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria poses a serious global health threat, making it increasingly difficult to treat common infections. Discovering novel antibacterial agents can help combat these resistant strains and ensure effective treatment options remain available. In this study, eighteen novel fluorobenzhydrazide derivatives, including linear thiosemicarbazides and cyclic 1,2,4-triazoles, were synthesized and evaluated for their in vitro antibacterial activity against various bacterial strains. Among the synthesized compounds, thiosemicarbazide 6, which contains a diethylaminophenyl substituent, exhibited moderate antibacterial activity, particularly against Gram-positive bacteria. This thiosemicarbazide successfully inhibited the growth of all Staphyloccocus aureus strains with an MIC of 64 µg/mL. To explore the potential antibacterial mechanism, molecular docking and molecular dynamics simulations were performed to assess the interaction of these compounds with Ddl ligase and DNA gyrase. Notably, 4-(4-N,N-diethylaminophenyl)-1-(3-fluorobenzoyl)thiosemicarbazide demonstrated a binding mode comparable to that of a known inhibitor, highlighting its potential as a lead compound and suggesting possible directions for further structural modifications.

title: Effect of Gum Acacia on the Pharmacokinetics of Metformin and Lisinopril in Mice
authors: Mohammed Al Tobi; Mohammed Ahmed Al-Aamri; Yousuf Al Suleimani; Mohammed Al Za’abi

title: Effects of Tanshinone ⅡA on Intestinal Microflora Diversity and Immune Function in Rats With Irritable Bowel Syndrome
authors: H Mao; Qing Li; Chengxia Gong Gong; Kang-jian Zhang; D S Han
abstract: Objective: To investigate the effects of tanshinone II A on intestinal flora diversity and immune function in a rat model of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Methods: Thirty SD rats were randomly divided into three groups: control (A, n=10), model (B, n=10), and experimental (C, n=10). IBS was induced in groups B and C using a water avoidance stress test. After successful modeling, group C received 10 mg/kg of tanshinone II A, while group B received saline. Immunohistochemistry was used to detect CRF expression in the terminal ileum. High-throughput sequencing analyzed microbial abundance and diversity. The expression of IL-6, IL-10, IL-17, IL-23 (via PCR), and STAT3/p-STAT3 (via Western blot) in the ileum were also assessed. Results: CRF expression in the submucosa and muscle layer was higher in group B compared to A, but reduced in group C compared to B. Lactobacillus and Enterobacteriaceae levels were increased in group B compared to A, but decreased in group C compared to B. STAT3 and p-STAT3 levels, along with IL-6, IL-17, and IL-23 mRNA, were elevated in group B, while IL-10 mRNA was reduced. In group C, IL-6, IL-17, and IL-23 levels decreased, and IL-10 increased. Conclusion: Tanshinone II A has a therapeutic effect on IBS in rats by regulating intestinal flora, reducing CRF expression, improving immune function, and inhibiting the STAT3 signaling pathway.

title: Acknowledgement to Reviewers 2024
authors: Michał Tomczyk
abstract: We would like to take this opportunity to thank you for the effort and expertise that you contribute to reviewing, without which it would be impossible to maintain the high editorial standards of Acta Poloniae Pharmaceutica – Drug Research.

title: Relative Bioavailability of Ticagrelor from Hard Capsules and Film-Coated Tablets in Healthy Caucasian Volunteers
authors: Michał Kaza; Agnieszka Gierczak‐Pachulska; Katarzyna Jarus‐Dziedzic; Olga Czerepow-Bielik; Agnieszka Segiet; Grzegorz Huszcza; Michał Hulak; Daniel Rabczenko; Piotr J. Rudzki
abstract: Ticagrelor is an active pharmaceutical ingredient of the first oral medicinal product inhibiting adenosine diphosphate-induced platelet aggregation by reversibly binding to P2Y12 receptor. It is co-administered with acetylsalicylic acid in patients with acute coronary syndromes or a history of myocardial infarction with high risk of cardiovascular events. The aim of study was to evaluate relative bioavailability of ticagrelor from two oral pharmaceutical forms hard capsules (Tikozek, test product) vs. film-coated tablets (Brilique®, reference product) after a single 90 mg dose administration. A randomized, 2-period, crossover, open-label, and laboratory-blinded study was conducted in healthy Caucasian male and female volunteers in Poland. Ticagrelor in human plasma was quantified by a validated LC-MS/MS method using isotope labelled internal standard. Two pharmaceutical forms were considered bioequivalent when 90% confidence intervals (CI) of the log-transformed geometric mean ratios (hard capsules over film-coated tablets) for both AUC(0-t) and Cmax were within 80.00-125.00%. Adverse events, values of laboratory parameters, and vital signs were recorded during the study. Among 40 volunteers enrolled, 37 completed the study. Geometric mean ratios for the primary pharmacokinetic parameter were 100.51% (90% CI 95.00-106.34%) for AUC(0-t), and 92.43% (90% CI 84.11-101.58%) for Cmax. Ticagrelor administered in both pharmaceutical forms was well tolerated. No serious adverse events were recorded. Results of the clinical trial indicate that hard capsules (Tikozek) are bioequivalent to the film-coated tablets (Brilique®).

title: Efficacy and Safety of Piperacillin/Tazobactam in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Patients With Infection: A Retrospective, Single-Center Cohort Study
authors: Yaya Guo; Chun Fa Huang; H Zhang
abstract: Background: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a systemic autoimmune disease with complex pathogenesis and diverse clinical manifestations. Infection is currently a common complication in patients with SLE and is the leading cause of death in patients with SLE. This study assessed the efficacy and safety of piperacillin/tazobactam in treating infections in SLE patients. Methods: This study included 48 patients diagnosed with SLE from January 2020 to June 2022. A retrospective review was conducted on SLE patients with infections treated with piperacillin/tazobactam. General demographic information, clinical signs, indicators from lab tests, and medication use were gathered. Then we compared the data from before and after the piperacillin/tazobactam treatment. Results: Among 48 SLE patients enrolled (44 with pulmonary infections), the anti-infective treatment success rate was 72.9%, with no serious adverse reactions reported. After treatment, levels of anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies, complement3 (C3), C4, creatinine, urea, and creatinine and creatinine clearance (CCr) showed no significant changes, indicating no worsening of lupus disease activity or renal function. In contrast, serum uric acid levels decreased significantly after treatment (p = 0.001). Conclusion: Piperacillin/tazobactam is effective and safe for SLE patients with infections. During this process, skin tests should be done in advance, the patient's response should be closely monitored, and the doctor should be closely communicated to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the treatment.

title: Berberine Inhibits Colon Cancer Progression Through MiR-181a/PTEN/PI3K/Akt Axis in Rats
authors: Chen Li; Xu Li
abstract: Aim: To evaluate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of berberine (BBR) on colon cancer (CC). Methods: Rats were randomly divided into normal, CC, BBR (20, 40, 80 mg/kg), and positive control paclitaxel (Pacl, 5 mg/kg) groups. Except for the normal group, CC was induced using 1,2-dimethylhydrazine (DMH). From the second week of DMH induction, the BBR and Pacl groups received BBR or Pacl daily, while the normal and CC groups received saline for 4 weeks. Observations included body mass, tumor mass and volume, spleen and thymus indices. Serum TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-10 were measured by ELISA, and protein expressions of c-Myc, ki67, cyclin D, cleaved-caspase 3, cleaved-caspase 9, PTEN, Akt, PI3K, and p-Akt were analyzed by western blot. MiR-181a expression was examined by RT-qPCR. Results: In the CC group, body mass, spleen and thymus indices, serum IL-10, and cleaved-caspase 3, cleaved-caspase 9, and PTEN in colon tissue were decreased, while tumor mass, volume, serum TNF-α, IL-6, and c-Myc, ki67, cyclin D, PI3K, p-Akt/Akt, and miR-181a were increased. Compared to CC, the BBR and Pacl groups showed improved body mass, spleen and thymus indices, and increased IL-10, cleaved-caspase 3, cleaved-caspase 9, and PTEN, with reduced tumor mass, volume, TNF-α, IL-6, c-Myc, ki67, cyclin D, PI3K, p-Akt/Akt, and miR-181a (P<0.05). Conclusion: In CC models, BBR exhibits anti-tumor effects, likely through down-regulation of miR-181a, promoting PTEN expression and inhibiting PI3K/Akt pathway activation.

title: Preparation and Stability Evaluation of Mesna Oral Solution From Commercially Available Tablets for Pediatric Patients
authors: Samiah Alhabardi; Norah Oudah Alotaibi; Alanood S. Almurshedi; Basmah N. Aldosari; Noura Aldosari; Wedad S. Sarawi
abstract: This research focused on the formulation and evaluation of a pediatric oral solution of mesna, a chemoprotective agent used to mitigate urotoxicity associated with chemotherapy drugs such as ifosfamide and cyclophosphamide. Given the challenges faced by pediatric patients in swallowing tablets, an extemporaneous oral solution was developed to improve accessibility and compliance. The formulation process involved adjusting the pH to approximately 3 using citric acid, which not only enhanced mesna's water solubility but also acted as an antioxidant and flavor enhancer. The study assessed the physicochemical stability of the mesna solution over a 90-day period, evaluating parameters such as color stability, pH consistency, and drug content. Results demonstrated that the oral solution maintained its physicochemical properties, with minimal changes in pH and drug concentration, indicating good stability under refrigerated conditions. Additionally, microbiological evaluations confirmed the safety of the formulation. This study highlights the potential of an extemporaneous mesna oral solution as a viable alternative for pediatric patients, ensuring effective treatment while addressing challenges related to medication administration or shortage.

title: Multifunctional Spray Applicators for Local Administration of Liquid Compounded Drugs
authors: Krzysztof Niwiński; Aldona Maciejewska; Weronika Gurda
abstract: This study evaluated the usefulness of multifunctional spray applicators for topical administration of compounded liquid medications. The research investigated the impact of liquid properties and applicator design on spray characteristics. Six atomizer types (lateral, horizontal long/short tip, and vertical) were tested with five solvents. The study assessed droplet size distribution, dose consistency, priming activations required, actuation force, residual volume, and suitability for suspensions. Results showed that for water, the average droplet size is in the range of approximately 83 to 124 µm. The viscosity has a significant impact on spray performance. In the case of high-viscosity solution of Celugel, some of the liquid does not atomize and is not detected, with only smaller droplets reaching the detector in reduced quantities (from about 33 to 67% compared to the number of water droplets generated). Concurrently, the droplet size ranges, depending on the atomizer type, from approximately 60% to approximately 120% of the water droplet size. Depending on the type of applicator and the fluid being dispensed, the force required to activate the pump mechanism was similar and ranged from 16 to 27 N, enabling comfortable application. Dose consistency was within 25% of manufacturer specifications, though significant differences were noted between vertical nasal applicators. All atomizers required multiple activations, ranging from 4 to 10 presses, depending on the solvent and the type of sprayer. The study emphasizes the importance of selecting the appropriate applicator and considering formulation properties, especially viscosity, for consistent dosing and effective drug delivery in compounded medications.

title: Renal-Protective Roles of Cornuside in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Model
authors: S. B. Wang; Shilei Ding; YULING WANG; Chuntao He; Yi Jen Jiang; YAO YAO; Di Zhu
abstract: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disorder often accompanied by renal injury. Current therapies face challenges due to adverse effects, necessitating safer alternatives. Cornuside, a bioactive compound from Cornus officinalis, demonstrates anti-inflammatory properties, but its role in SLE remains unexplored. This study investigated cornuside’s protective effects in pristane-induced SLE mice. Results showed cornuside significantly reduced proteinuria, paw swelling, and renal inflammation. Mechanistically, cornuside suppressed proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-17, TNF-α), and activated Nrf-2/ARE-mediated antioxidant responses (HO-1 upregulation). These findings highlight cornuside’s potential as a novel therapeutic agent for SLE-associated renal injury.

title: Formulation of a Positively Charged Testosterone Niosome-Loaded Hydrogel: Optimization, IVIVC Correlation, and pharmacokinetic evaluation
authors: Saeid Mezail Mawazi; Roy Rillera Marzo; Mohammed Aljuaid; Nausneen Fathima; Yi Ge; Riyanto Teguh Widodo
abstract: The present study deals with the formulation of a hydrogel based on the positively charged niosomes for the delivery of testosterone at an improved skin permeation rate and offering sustained release. Testosterone-loaded niosomes (F1, F2, F3) were prepared with different concentrations of an octadecyl amine as a positive charge inducer combined with Span 60, Tween 60, and cholesterol; subsequently, these were incorporated into a hydrogel matrix of xanthan gum, iota carrageenan, and hyaluronic acid. Characterization confirmed stability, encapsulation efficiency, and diffusion-controlled drug release for each formulation. In vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo pharmacokinetic studies demonstrated that formulation H3, with the highest concentration of octadecyl amine, achieved maximum release and systemic absorption compared to H1, H2, and the marketed Androgel reference. Strong IVIVC correlation supports the potential of niosome-based hydrogel for the transdermal delivery of testosterone and that HF provided an optimized and sustained release of the hormone for clinical applications in hormone replacement therapy.

title: Hyperoside Suppresses High Glucose-Evoked Inflammation and Fibrosis in Glomerular Mesangial cells by Downregulating lncRNA RMRP
authors: J. Li; Qing Fang; Y. Wang; Fei Sheng
abstract: Objective: Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is one of the serious microvascular complications of diabetes mellitus. Diabetic condition or hyperglycaemia induces profibrotic reactions, which ultimately cause glomerulosclerosis. Hyperoside (HP) possesses diverse biological actions, including cardiovascular, renal, neuroprotective, antifibrotic, and anticancer effects. This study aimed to determine the underlying mechanism of HP on high glucose (HG)-evoked inflammation and fibrosis in glomerular mesangial cells (GMCs). Methods: GMCs were respectively cultured in DMEM medium with 0 or 30 mmol /L D-glucose, termed as negative control (Con) and HG groups. HG group were respectively treated with 4, 8, or 16 nmol/L HP, generating HG+HP-L/-M/-H groups. si-NC or si-lncRNA RMRP -transfected GMCs were treated with 30 mmol /L D-glucose, termed as HG+si-NC, HG+si-lncRNA RMRP. pcDNA or pcDNA-lncRNA RMRP -transfected GMCs were treated with 30 mmol /L D-glucose and 16 nmol/L HP, termed as HG+HP-H+pcDNA, and HG+HP-H+ pcDNA-lncRNA RMRP group. ELISA analyzed IL-6, IL-10 and TNF-α. Western blot detected connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), endothelin-1 (ET-1), and fibronectin (FN) protein levels. RT-qPCR detected lncRNA RMRP levels. Results: HP or lncRNA RMRP silencing decreased IL-6 and TNF-α levels, ET-1, FN and CTGF protein contents, and increased IL-10 levels (P<0.05). HP treatment down-regulated HG-evoked increase of lncRNA RMRP (P<0.05), and lncRNA RMRP up-regulation reversed the inhibition of HP on inflammatory response and fibrosis in GMCSs (P<0.05). HG+HP-H treatment group is the most effective. Conclusion: HP inhibits GMC inflammation and fibrosis induced by HG through down-regulating lncRNA RMRP, providing new insight to the current investigation on therapeutic strategies for DN.

title: Investigation of Enhancement Delivery of Camptothecin Through Hydroxy Propyl-β-Cyclodextrin Complexation, Loaded on Pegylated Rutin Liposomes
authors: Rawaa Mohammed Ahmed; Israa Al‐Ani; Ali Al‐Samydai; Areej M. Jaber; Hamdi Nsairat; Ali Al kinani
abstract: Camptothecin (CPT) is a potent topoisomerase I inhibitor with promising anticancer potential. However, its poor solubility and stability present major obstacles in pharmaceutical formulations. Rutin, a plant-derived quercetin glycoside, also exhibits anticancer activity but suffers from limited solubility. This study explores a novel combination of CPT and Rutin in a liposomal drug delivery system. To enhance CPT solubility and encapsulation, hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HPβCD) complexation was employed. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with UV detection was used for analysis. The CPT-HPβCD complex was prepared via different methods and characterized by Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectroscopy, and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR). Liposomes loaded with Rutin and CPT-HPβCD were formulated and evaluated for size, charge, encapsulation efficiency, and in vitro release. Results showed that the solubility of CPT was significantly increased from 1.09µM to a range of (1.68-8.5) µM using different concentrations of HPβCD. Characterization proved the formation of the complex and the kneading method of preparation was found to be superior to other methods like solvent evaporation with an encapsulation efficiency of 64.6 ± 2.5%. The prepared Liposomes showed particle size around 20 nm with negative charge and 60 % cumulative release of rutin from the liposomes was achieved and CPT up to 60% compared to 10 % from the formula 1 (without complexation) with controlled release pattern.

title: Characterization of Itraconazole Solid Dispersions: Comparative Analysis of Supercritical CO2 and Electrospinning Preparation Methods
authors: Jolanta Pyteraf; Agata Antosik; Ewelina Łyszczarz; Przemysław Talik; Aleksander Mendyk
abstract: The poor solubility of active compounds and the stability of solid dispersions containing processed drugs are among the main challenges in pharmaceutical research. This study investigates the potential for improving the solubility of itraconazole (ITR) through solid dispersion formulations using two different carriers (Polyvinylpyrrolidone K30 and Eudragit E 100) at two API : polymer weight ratios (1:2 and 1:5). Two different solvent-based methods for preparing solid dispersions – supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) and electrospinning (Esp) – were introduced. The results confirmed improvement in ITR solubility and dissolution, as well as changes in particle shape and size for both weight ratio formulations. After processing, a decrease in ITR crystallinity was observed. The results indicated that an increased amount of carriers led to better results. Consequently, these formulations were selected for stability studies. The samples were packed into aluminum sachets and stored in climate chambers under long-term (25°C, 60%RH) and accelerated (40°C, 75%RH) conditions for one month. We demonstrated the scCO2 samples were resistant to storage; neither the temperature nor humidity affected the properties of solid dispersions. In contrast, samples obtained via electrospinning were more sensitive to storage conditions.

title: Anti-Inflammatory, Antioxidant, and Analgesic Effects of Nitrophenylthiazole Acetamide in a Papain-Induced Osteoarthritis Rat Model
authors: Xin Feng
abstract: Abstract: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease characterized by cartilage degradation, inflammation, oxidative stress, and pain. This study aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a nitrophenylthiazole acetamide, 6a, in a papain-induced OA rat model. OA was induced by intra-articular injection of papain, followed by oral administration of compound 6a at doses of 2.5, 5, and 10 mg/kg. Knee joint diameter and mechanical allodynia were assessed using caliper measurements and the Von Frey pain threshold test, respectively. Oxidative stress markers (MDA, SOD, and GSH), pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6), and mRNA expression levels of NLRP3, ASC, and caspase-1 were also evaluated. Results demonstrated that compound 6a significantly reduced joint swelling and increased pain threshold in a dose-dependent manner. Biochemical analysis revealed a marked decrease in MDA levels, along with significant increases in SOD and GSH, indicating strong antioxidant activity. Furthermore, compound 6a suppressed the elevated levels of TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6 and downregulated the mRNA expression of NLRP3, ASC, and caspase-1, suggesting inhibition of inflammasome-mediated inflammation. In conclusion, compound 6a exhibited notable anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and analgesic effects in the OA rat model, highlighting its potential as a promising therapeutic agent for osteoarthritis management.

title: Serum Proteomic Analysis in Obese Postmenopausal Women Before and After Multi-Species Probiotic Supplementation
authors: Matylda Kręgielska-Narożna; Ewa Miller‐Kasprzak; Eliza Matuszewska; Jan Matysiak; Katarzyna Skrypnik; Igor Łoniewski; Monika Szulińska; Paweł Bogdański
abstract: The composition and functions of the gut microbiota can affect the development of obesity and metabolic disorders. Proteomics analysis has become important tool for characterizing the proteome and identifying serum biomarkers associated with specific conditions in different groups of patients. The aim of this study was to gain insight into the pathophysiological aspects of obesity and the relation between comorbidities and the gut microbiota by characterizing the protein profile in obese post-menopausal women before and after multi-species probiotic supplementation. MALDI-TOF MS analyses were performed in serum samples from the placebo group 24, from the low-dose probiotic group 24, and 23 from the high-dose probiotic group. Paired comparison analysis of protein–peptide patterns derived from patients at two time points (i.e., before and after treatment) revealed several peaks changing under treatment. Complement C3, Fibrinogen alpha chain, Coagulation factor XII, Tubulin beta-3 chain, Fibrinogen beta chain, Inter-alpha-trypsin inhibitor heavy chain H4, and Apolipoprotein A-I were identified. Depending on the administered dose, slightly different alterations were observed. In summary, the obtained results do not allow us to draw a conclusion regarding the influence of probiotic supplementation on peptide profile in obese post-menopausal women. However some of identified proteins could take part in the complex mechanism involving obesity, dysbiosis, and inflammation. Registration number: NCT03100162

title: Herbal Therapeutics in Cardiovascular Disease: A Review
authors: P. Bao
abstract: Herbal have gained recognition as valuable adjuncts in managing cardiovascular disease (CVD), offering multi-targeted benefits across key risk factors. This review summarizes data from different data bases over the past decade, focusing on herbs with traditional and emerging cardiovascular applications. The selection is supported by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and its Committee on Herbal Medicinal Products (HMPC) monographs. Key herbs include artichoke (Cynara cardunculus L. syn. Cynara scolymus L.) turmeric (Curcuma longa L.), Citrus bergamia (Citrus bergamia Risso & Poit.), garlic (Allium sativum L.), ginkgo (Ginkgo biloba L.), danshen (Salvia miltiorrhiza Bunge), hawthorn (Crataegus spp.), Terminalia arjuna (Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn.), Asian ginseng (Panax ginseng C.A.Meyer.), green tea (Camellia sinensis (L.) Kuntze), ginger (Zingiber officinale Roscoe), black cumin (Nigella sativa L.), motherwort (Leonurus cardiaca L), and others. These plants are rich in bioactive compounds such as flavonoids, polyphenols, and organosulfur compounds, which exert antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antihypertensive, and lipid-lowering effects. Clinical evidence supports garlic’s impact on blood pressure and lipids, hawthorn’s benefits in heart failure, and ginseng and ginkgo’s role in vascular function. Curcumin and gingerols contribute to anti-inflammatory activity and improved metabolic profiles. Additional herbs like bergamot and hibiscus also show cholesterol- and blood pressure-lowering effects. While the overall safety profile is favourable, herb–drug interactions must be considered. Collectively, these herbal agents offer a natural, accessible, and cost-effective complement to conventional CVD therapies. However, further large-scale clinical trials are essential to confirm efficacy, establish standardized dosing, and evaluate long-term safety in cardiovascular care.

title: MiR-204 Inhibits Thyroid Cancer Cell Proliferation, Apoptosis, and Migration Through Targeting HMGB1 Expression
authors: Min Yu; Yongzhi Liu; Xiaoying Zhou
abstract: Thyroid cancer incidence is rising globally, yet early diagnosis remains challenging due to the lack of initial symptoms, highlighting the need for novel molecular targets. miR-204, a tumor-suppressive microRNA downregulated in various cancers, has unclear mechanisms in thyroid cancer. This study explored how miR-204 affects thyroid cancer cell behavior by targeting high-mobility group protein B1 (HMGB1). Tumor and adjacent tissues from 40 thyroid cancer patients (Feb 2019–June 2021) and multiple thyroid cancer cell lines (TPC-1, NPA87, FTC133) were analyzed. miR-204 was significantly downregulated in cancer tissues and cells (P < 0.05), with the lowest expression in FTC133 cells. These cells were transfected and divided into experimental groups (e.g., miR-204 mimics, inhibitors, si-HMGB1). Overexpression of miR-204 suppressed proliferation and migration and promoted apoptosis in FTC133 cells, while its inhibition had the opposite effect (P < 0.05). Luciferase assays confirmed HMGB1 as a direct target of miR-204. HMGB1 knockdown reduced proliferation and migration and increased apoptosis, effects reversed by miR-204 inhibition (P < 0.05). In summary, miR-204 inhibits thyroid cancer cell progression and promotes apoptosis, likely by directly targeting HMGB1, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target.

title: Leveraging Microwaves as a Process Analytical Technology (PAT) Tool in the Pharmaceutical Industry
authors: Mateusz Mróz; Małgorzata Sznitowska
abstract: To ensure product quality and consistency, as well as compliance with regulatory standards, the pharmaceutical industry has turned to innovative solutions. One such solution is Process Analytical Technology (PAT), which has the potential to transform pharmaceutical manufacturing by enabling real-time monitoring and control of critical parameters and attributes. The review presents microwave resonance technology (MRT) as a PAT tool that can be used for in-line monitoring of the drying process after granulation step in the manufacturing of solid oral dosage forms. This new technique is an alternative to more popular method based on near infrared (NIR) technology. The article explores the principles of microwave measurement technology, activities required for MRT deployment in a commercial setting and challenges that need to be considered whilst using MRT.

title: Exploring the Impact of Standardized Melissa officinalis Extract and Key Phenolic Acids on the Contractility of Isolated Jejunum and Colon Segments in Pigs
authors: Marta Mendel; Martyna Posłuszny; Magdalena Chłopecka; Sorphon Suor Chererb; Sekhou Cisse; Mohamed Amine Ben Rabia
abstract: Background: The rising global demand for animal protein necessitates sustainable and efficient livestock production. This study explored the effects of Melissa officinalis extract and its main phenolic acids on the motility of the swine jejunum and colon, with the aim of verifying its usefulness as a health-promoting feed additive. The trials were performed on isolated jejunum and colon preparations and verified the effects of Melissa officinalis extract and 3 phenolic acids (rosmarinic, chlorogenic, and lithospermic) on spontaneous and acetylcholine (ACh)-induced smooth muscle activity under isometric conditions. Results: The study revealed the antispasmodic effect of Melissa extract. The preparation reduced by about 50% the control contraction when used at the highest tested dose (0.1 mg/ml). The results suggest that rosmarinic acid contributes the most to the eventual effect on the plant. In contrast, chlorogenic acid was a potent myocontractile agent under all the studied conditions and models. Conclusions: The major outcome of the study is the confirmation of the utility of a standardized extract of lemon balm as an antispasmodic agent in jejunum and colon specimens challenged with ACh, i.e., the most important stimulatory neurotransmitter in the enteric nervous system. Owing to the lack of data revealing the effects of lemon balm extract and individual phenolic acids on spontaneous contractility, it is impossible to conclude indisputably about their contributions to the final effects on the plant. Nevertheless, this study highlights the potential of Melissa officinalis to modulate intestinal motility in pigs experiencing hypermotility disorders, mainly microbial infections.

title: Shifting From a Medication Dispensing Model to a Patient-Centered Approach: Community Pharmacy Development in Poland and Portugal
authors: Julia Cynar; Afonso Cavaco; Elżbieta Nowakowska; Krzysztof Kus; Piotr Ratajczak; Anna Paczkowska; Dorota Kopciuch; Tomasz Zaprutko
abstract: To meet patient needs more effectively, healthcare systems must adopt a cost-effective, patient-centred ap-proach that prioritizes primary care over secondary care. Community pharmacies play a key role in this shift, expanding beyond medication dispensing to offer a broader range of healthcare services. This study compares community pharmacy services in Poland and Portugal to assess whether Poland is behind, aligned with, or different in its approach. A narrative review examined community pharmacy services in Poland and Portugal, using Portugal as a reference due to its well-established pharmaceutical care system. The literature was searched in databases such as PubMed, Embase, and Google Scholar from January to March 2025 along with legal regulations and government public announcements, to provide a thorough understanding of the subject. While Portuguese pharmacists have long been involved in immunization, diagnosis, and prevention, these services are still in the early stages of development in Poland. Polish pharmacists, in turn, have broader author-ity to issue prescriptions in health or life-threatening situations. In Poland, expanding pharmacists' services, particularly in diagnosis and prevention could improve healthcare accessibility and support physicians in man-aging patient care. In Portugal, on the other hand, granting pharmacists broader prescribing authority could enhance patient access to essential medicines in emergency situations and ease the burden on the health care system, enabling it to respond more quickly to patients' needs.

title: Nifuroxazide Adverse Drug Reaction Characteristics and Descriptive Analysis From VigiAccess and EudraVigilance Databases
authors: Monika Birska; Karolina Kłosowska; Grażyna Bodalska; Katarzyna Karłowicz-Bodalska; Gabriela Jaryczewska
abstract: Nifuroxazide is a nitrofuran derivative with proven efficacy in the treatment of both acute and chronic bacterial diarrhea. The aim of this study is to assess the safety profile of nifuroxazide and to evaluate the occurrence of adverse drug reactions (ADRs). A retrospective descriptive analysis of ADR reports related to nifuroxazide use was conducted. Data sources included databases: the European EudraVigilance (2001–May 2025) and the global VigiAccess (1980–May 2025). The analysis focused on patient demographics, symptomatology, and the frequency of adverse events. The VigiAccess database documented 846 cases of ADRs up to 2025, approximately 60% of which were reported in the last decade. The highest incidence of ADRs was observed in individuals aged 18 to 64 years with predominant reactions concerning skin and subcutaneous tissue (rash, pruritus, urticaria, angioedema). Most frequent systemic symptoms were facial edema, shivers, and malaise. The EudraVigilance database (2001–2025) reported 439 cases of ADRs, predominantly in individuals aged 18 to 64 years. The most frequently observed adverse effects included dermatological reactions, facial edema, malaise and gastrointestinal disturbances. The analysis of ADR reports from VigiAccess and EudraVigilance supports a favorable safety profile of nifuroxazide, reinforcing its efficacy in bacterial infections of the gastrointestinal tract. Nifuroxazide is recommended as a first-line treatment for mild cases of infectious diarrhea, serving as an alternative to systemic antibiotics reserved for more severe infections. Enhancing awareness among healthcare professionals and patients regarding ADR monitoring is crucial for optimizing pharmacovigilance and ensuring the safe use of nifuroxazide in clinical practice.

title: Therapeutic Effect of Tannic Acid Mediated Antibacterial ZnO Nanoparticles for Wound Healing in ICU Care — In Vitro Anti-Inflammatory, Antimicrobial, Antioxidant Studies
authors: Liu Haimu; Yunzhe Zhen
abstract: A novel class of antibacterial substances has emerged as a result of the size and structure of metal nanoparticles. The study outlines a green method to produce Zinc oxide nanoparticles, with aqueous tannic acid functioning dual roles: as a capping agent and a structural director. The resulting ZnO NPs underwent detailed characterization through a variety of microscopic and spectroscopic methods, followed by investigations into their anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant effects, all aiming to evaluate their potential future role in wound healing. scanning transmission electron microscope images revealed that prepared ZnO NPs are about 8±2 nm in size without any aggregation. Comparative studies of the anti-inflammatory abilities of ZnO NPs and a standard drug revealed the nanoparticles to exhibit significant anti-inflammatory activity at elevated concentrations (100 mL-1), with a 73% inhibition rate when compared with the diclofenac sodium drug. This led to the conclusion that ZnO is compatible with diclofenac sodium. Furthermore, the manufactured ZnO NPs showcased effective antibacterial and antioxidant activities. Enhanced antibacterial activity was attributed to the surface tannic acid, which possibly influence the release of Zn2+ ions and the generation of Reactive Oxygen Species. Additional examination with 3- (4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide cell viability analysis on fibroblast cells confirmed an improvement in biocompatibility showing that more than 90% of cell viability, as evidenced by the growth of the fibroblast cells. In summary, the findings indicate that the biosynthesized ZnO NPs, which were synthesized using tannic acid, have significant potential for future use in wound care, particularly in ICU care.

title: Use of Topological Indices to Predict Structure-Property Relationships of Selected Drugs
authors: Dawid Wardecki; Małgorzata Dołowy; Katarzyna Bober
abstract: The purpose of this work aimed to determine different topological indices based on adjacency and distance matrix for selected antimicrobial, antiviral and immunosuppressive drug substances. The following topological indices: Gutman (M, Mν), Randić (0χ, 1χ, 0χν, 1χν), Wiener (W), Rouvray-Crafford (R) and Pyka (A, 0B, 1B) were calculated for the studied compounds. Furthermore, these indices were related with various physicochemical properties of these compounds including those key in the ADME process (absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion), such as lipophilicity parameters obtained using both theoretical (logP values) and experimental (RMW values from thin-layer chromatography) methods. The quantitative structure–property relationship (QSPR) analysis of presented topological indices shows a good correlation of studied descriptors with certain physicochemical properties of examined drugs. The obtained linear regression models can be helpful to predict these physicochemical properties of new derivatives of tested compounds and thus are significant in pharmaceutical product design. This study confirms that the newly calculated descriptors (TIs) represent an innovative tool in drug analysis and at the same time TIs are useful in determining important parameters for ADME profile prediction.

title: Ameliorative Effects of Kiwifruit and Star Anise on the Negative Effects Induced by Ehrlich Ascites Carcinoma on Bone Marrow
authors: Dalia I. Hemdan; Mahmoud Rokaya; Taqwa Bushnaq; Khadija S. Radhi; Ohaad F. Awlya; Dina Ismaeil Hemdan
abstract: Kiwi fruit (Actinidia deliciosa) and star anise (Illicium verum) are the richest sources of minerals and vitamins. Fractionation of phenolic compounds by HPLC for kiwi fruit showed that the main compounds in the methanol extract were syringic acid, chrysin, and quercetin. Star anise had the highest concentrations of syringic acid, quercetin, and gallic acid, respectively. Mice in biological experiments were divided into six groups. Group I was the negative control, while Group II was the positive control, and they were both injected with EAC. Group III was injected with EAC and the chemical drug cisplatin. Groups IV, V, and VI mice were injected with EAC separately and treated with kiwifruit juice, star anise, and a mixture of kiwifruit juice and star anise. The results showed that cell viability was best in kiwi fruit, followed by the mixture and star anise. In contrast, the treatment with cisplatin as chemotherapy for EAC resulted in lower cell viability compared to the different juices. Mice in Groups IV, V, and VI, as well as those treated with cisplatin, were observed to have an increased expansion of myeloid cells (CD11b+LY6G+). The results from flow cytometry indicated enhanced levels of CD69 and CD62L, in addition to CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in the various experimental mice groups. It can be concluded that kiwi fruit and star anise have high nutritional value and the highest concentrations of phenolic compounds. These characteristics contribute to a high activity of natural antioxidants and medicinal properties.

title: Pretreatment With Hyssopus officinalis Ethyl Acetate Leaf Extract Mitigates Gastric Mucosal Injury: A Potential Gastroprotective Strategy
authors: Nour-el-Houda Hamoud; Zineb Maammeri
abstract: Peptic ulcer disease continues to pose a significant health burden in the area of gastrointestinal diseases, while ethanol-induced gastric damage is a well-established experimental model for developing and testing mucosal protective agents. In this investigation, we evaluated the gastroprotective efficacy of the ethyl acetate leaf extract of Hyssopus officinalis (EALE) in ethanol-induced gastric mucosal injury in rats, and tried to assess the phytochemical constituents of EALE using ultra-performance liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-ESI-MS/MS). Our findings indicate that pretreatment with EALE at doses of 250 and 500 mg/kg protected against gastric lesions induced by ethanol, with the 500 mg/kg dose completely preventing gastric ulceration (100% inhibition) and more efficaciously than the clinically-utilized omeprazole treatment (86% inhibition, 80 mg/kg). Histopathological analysis showed only intact mucosa indicating no evidence of damage to the tissue in the 500 mg/kg group. Using UPLC-ESI-MS/MS, we characterized a rich phytochemical profile that included 20 metabolites from the EALE, such as phenolic acids, flavonoids, quinones, and vitamins. The major compounds (quercetin 24.09%, esculin acid 24.37%, hesperetin acid 20.46%, and naringenin 8.63%) likely contributed to the cytoprotective implications of EALE. The results of this study support H. officinalis as a natural therapeutic agent with gastroprotective activity and further its development as a new dietary adjunct for gastric ulcers

title: Determination of active substances in binary mixture antiparasitic veterinary formulations by HPLC.
authors: Anna Kulik; Aleksandra Szczotkowska; Wanda Białecka; Marzena Podolska; Barbara Kwiatkowska-Puchniarz; Aleksander P. Mazurek
abstract: The purpose of the study was to develop a simple, versatile HPLC method for the identification and quantification of praziquantel and ivermectin (in Equimax) or praziquantel and abamectin (in Abamitel Plus). A satisfactory separation was obtained using the Supelcosil LC-ABZ+ column in gradient system with a mobile phase A: acetonitrile / water in 40:60 ratio and phase B: acetonitrile. The UV detection was set at 245 nm. The correlation coefficient values (> or = 0,998) for all active substances confirmed that the calibration curves (peak area vs. concentration) are linear. The results of the quantification and the statistical evaluation confirmed that the method is accurate and precise. It can also be applied to confirm the identity of benzyl alcohol, methyl p-hydroxybenzoate and propyl p-hydroxybenzoate in Abamitel Plus formulation.

title: BIOLOGICAL ACTIVITIES OF DIFFERENT EXTRACTS FROM ALLIUM URSINUM LEAVES
authors: Marina Tomović; Miloš Krivokapić; Vladimir Jakovljević; Miroslav Sovrlić; Jovana Bradić; Anica Petković; Ivana D. Radojević; Snežana Branković; Ljiljana R. Čomić; Marijana Andjić; Aleksandar Kočović
abstract: Allium ursinum L. (A. ursinum, family Amaryllidaceae), better known under the name of wild garlic, ramson or bearís garlic is a perennial herbaceous plant.It naturally grows in fens and marshes of Europe and Asia (1-3).Increasingly, popular in European kitchen A. ursinum can be used as a salad, spice or vegetable since all parts of the plant are edible.Throughout history leaves, bulbs and the aerial part of this plant species have been used in traditional medicine as therapeutic and prophylactic agents (4-6).Numerous biologically active compounds enable this plant species to be implemented in the healing of various conditions for years.The most common are sulfur compounds which are considered to largely contribute to the pharmacological activity and from which originates a characteristic smell and taste (7).In addition to a significant presence of phenols, flavonoids, there are in a lesser extent other steroidal glycosides, amino acids, fatty acids, lecithin, essential oil (4, 8, 9).The aforementioned bioactive compounds can be exploited and used in the form of various extracts.Experimental investigations indicate the efficiency of the application A. ursinum in prevention and treatment of many diseases such as cardiovascular diseases, cancer, obesity, diabetes, disorders of the gastrointestinal tract, elevated cholesterol level, as well as the inflammatory diseases (10-14).Itís been known that the applied extraction method and extraction solvent may substantially affect the quality and concentration of targeted com-

title: Glaucocalyxin Attenuates Thyroid Cancer Cell Proliferation and Aggression Through Circ_0030018/miR-145
authors: Manyi Sun; Jiarui Li; Zhirui Xue; Lily M. Du
abstract: Aim To disclose the effects of glaucocalyxin A (GLA) on the growth and motivity of human thyroid cancer cells and its regulation on circ_0030018/miR-145. Methods TPC1 cells were challenged with diverse doses of GLA. MTT method, colony-formation test, scratch study and Transwell test were respectively used to exploit TPC1 cell behaviors. qRT-PCR method was adopted for the detection of of circ_0030018 and miR-145 expression. Dual-luciferase reporter experiment was adopted to verify the binding between circ_0030018 and miR-145. Western blotting was applied for the detection of MMP-2 and MMP-9 expression. Results After GLA treatment, the cell proliferative inhibition rate was considerably reinforced, while the amount of cell clone formation, the number of invasive cells, the cell scratch healing rate and the expressions of MMP-2 and MMP-9 were considerably lessened. GLA treatment weakened circ_0030018 expression but strengthened miR-145 expression. Circ_0030018 could target and regulate the expression of miR-145. The si-circ_0030018 transfection repressed TPC1 cell proliferation, reduced the number of cell clone formation and the number of invaded cells, and weakened the scar healing rate and the abundance of MMP-2 and MMP-9. Circ_0030018 upregulation could overturn the effects of GLA on TPC1 cell behaviors. Conclusion GLA could inhibit thyroid cancer cell proliferative and aggressive behaviors by regulating circ_0030018/miR-145.

title: Circ_0000003 Targets miR-615-3p to Affect Cervical Cancer Cell Proliferation, Apoptosis, and Cisplatin Sensitivity
authors: Yu Luo; Jianghua Xiao; Ruifu Zeng; Bing Zhou; Xin Fu
abstract: Abstract:Objective: For probing the impacts of circ_0000003 on pernicious evolvement and cisplatin susceptibility of DDP-resistant cervical cancer (CC) HeLa cells and its acting theory. Methods: RT-qPCR method tested the contents of circ_0000003 and miR-615-3p in CC cells. The influences of circ_0000003 silence or over-expression of miR-615-3p on proliferative capacity and cisplatin sensitivity, or apoptosis of HeLa/DDP cells were authenticated utilizing MTT and flow cytometer. The levels of related proteins in HeLa/DDP cells were tested using western blot. Dual luciferase reporter analysis was proceeded for checking the targeting relation of circ_0000003 and miR-615-3p. Results: Circ_0000003 and miR-615-3p contents in CC cells were signally incremental and lowered, severally. Circ_0000003 reduction or miR-615-3p enhancement restrained OD value, and raised apoptotic ratio and DDP sensibility in HeLa/DDP cells. miR-615-3p content was adjusted by circ_0000003 and interplayed with it. Disturbance of miR-615-3p mitigated circ_0000003 silence-mediated impacts on the progress and DDP sensibility of HeLa/DDP cells. Conclusion: The suppression of circ_0000003 may inhibit HeLa/DDP cells proliferation, promote apoptosis and enhance cisplatin sensitivity by targeting and upregulating miR-615-3p.

title: Therapeutic Effect and Mechanism of Cardamonin on Periodontitis Rats via Nrf2/HO-1/NLRP3 Signaling Pathway Regulation
authors: Wangtong Lu; Jing An; Jingjing Wang
abstract: Abstract: This study investigates the therapeutic effects of cardamonin on periodontitis rats and its involvement in the Nrf2/HO-1/NLRP3 signaling pathway. Fifty SD rats were divided into five groups: CON, MOD, L-CAR (15 mg/kg), H-CAR (60 mg/kg), and H-CAR+BRU (60 mg/kg + 2 mg/kg). ELISA was used to measure serum inflammatory and oxidative stress factors. Micro-CT assessed alveolar bone absorption, and HE staining evaluated periodontal tissue. TRAP staining was performed for osteoclast counting, and Western blot measured protein expression of OPG, RANKL, Nrf2, HO-1, and NLRP3. Results showed that, compared to the CON group, rats in the MOD group exhibited gingival erosion, widened periodontal ligament space, and increased inflammatory infiltration, along with reduced alveolar bone parameters (Tb.N, Tb.Th) and lower serum antioxidant levels (SOD, GSH-Px). In contrast, the L-CAR and H-CAR groups showed improved tissue morphology, increased alveolar bone parameters, and enhanced antioxidant levels. These groups also exhibited upregulation of Nrf2 and HO-1 and downregulation of NLRP3, RANKL, and osteoclast count. However, the H-CAR+BRU group showed exacerbated periodontal damage and further imbalance in inflammatory and bone resorption markers. In conclusion, cardamonin exerts therapeutic effects on periodontitis by activating the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway and inhibiting NLRP3-mediated inflammation and bone resorption.

title: Advancements in Predicting Adverse Drug Reactions Using Physiologically Based Pharmacokinetic Models: a Comprehensive Review
authors: Hui Liu; Z. Li; Qing Shao; Yueni Ning; Qingjun Guo
abstract: The physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) model plays a crucial role in predicting adverse drug reactions by simulating the processes of drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion under specific in vivo conditions. Recent advances in PBPK modelling have demonstrated its effectiveness in predicting various types of toxicities, including nephrotoxicity and cardiotoxicity, by translating complex pharmacokinetic behaviours into simplified mathematical expressions solvable by computers. These models provide critical insights into drug safety, allowing for early clinical warnings of potential adverse reactions. However, challenges remain, such as the need for more accurate physiological data and improved model validation methods. Future research should focus on refining these models and expanding their application to a broader range of drug toxicities to enhance clinical drug safety predictions.

title: Morroniside Inhibits apoptosis and Oxidative Stress in High Glucose-Induced Renal Tubular Epithelial Cells by Upregulating MiR-25
authors: Wei Wei; Huimin Wang; Byung Pal Yu
abstract: Objective: Morroniside has been shown to have anti-apoptotic and anti-oxidative stress effects, but its role in diabetic nephropathy (DN)-related cell injury is still unclear. This study aims to explore the role and mechanism of morroniside in DN progression. Methods: Human renal tubular epithelial cells (HK2) were cultured with high glucose (HG) and treated with morroniside. Cell proliferation and apoptosis were measured by cell counting kit 8 method and flow cytometry. Western blot was used to detect the protein levels of apoptosis marker Bax and anti-apoptosis marker Bcl-2. Malonaldehyde (MDA) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) levels were examined to evaluate cell oxidative stress, and miR-25 expression was determined by quantitative real-time PCR. Results: After treated with HG, cell viability, Bcl-2 level, SOD activity and miR-25 expression were decreased, whereas apoptosis rate, Bax level and MDA content were increased. Morroniside enhanced cell viability, Bcl-2 level, SOD activity and miR-25 expression, while reduced apoptosis rate, Bax level and MDA content in HG-induced HK2 cells. Overexpression of miR-25 promoted cell viability, repressed HG-induced HK2 cell apoptosis and oxidative stress. Knockdown of miR-25 reversed the effects of morroniside on the viability, apoptosis and oxidative stress in HG-induced HK2 cells. Conclusion: Morroniside could inhibit HG-induced HK2 cell injury via increasing miR-25 expression, confirming that morroniside might alleviate DN process.

title: Psoralen Targets Oxidative Stress, Protein Denaturation, Microbial Triggers, and Modulates CCN1, CCN2, and TNF-α in Rheumatoid Arthritis
authors: Guoliang Wang; Yang Wang; Baohua Cao
abstract: This study analyzed psoralen in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) using in-silico, in-vitro, and biochemical assays for its pharmacokinetic properties, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial effects, and cytokine regulation. The absorption–distribution–metabolism–excretion–toxicity (ADMET) analysis was performed using the pkCSM platform online. Cytotoxicity studies were conducted on SW-982 synovial cells using 3-[4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl]-2,5-diphenyl-tetrazolium-bromide (MTT) assays, and reactive-oxygen-species (ROS) production was measured to understand the mechanisms of oxidative stress. Anti-inflammatory effects were determined by Bovine-serum-albumin (BSA) protein denaturation assays, while antimicrobial activity against Porphyromonas gingivalis, Proteus mirabilis, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae was tested by minimum-inhibitory-concentration (MIC) and minimum-microbial-concentration (MMC) assays. Molecular-docking analyzed interactions of psoralen with Tumour-Necrosis-Factor-alpha (TNF-α), Cellular Communication Network Factor-1 and -2 (CCN1, and CCN2), and quantification of their expression was achieved by Western blotting. ADMET analysis showed that psoralen had high intestinal absorption, was non-hepatotoxic, and was devoid of mutagenic and cardiovascular risks, though it had poor Central-Nervous-System (CNS) permeability. MTT assays demonstrated dose- and time-dependent cytotoxicity with IC₅₀ values of ~40 µg/mL at 24 hours and ~35 µg/mL at 48 hours, which correlated with increased ROS production. Psoralen inhibited protein denaturation following concentration-dependent manner, competing with aspirin at higher doses. It showed antimicrobial activity with MIC values of 1.5–2.5 µg/mL and MMC/MIC ratios of 1.6–2.0. The molecular-docking demonstrated strong binding with TNF-α (-8.6), CCN1 (-7.5), and CCN2 (-6.5). Significant downregulation of these mediators was further confirmed by western blot analysis. Based on these outcomes, Psoralen has potential therapeutic applications in RA thus suggesting further research studies.

title: Modulation Of Nf-Κb Expression In Esophageal Cancer Cells by Andrographolide and Combined Effects With Radiotherapy
authors: Dong Peng
abstract: Background: Esophageal cancer (EC) maintains a visible disease burden in China, constituting a major public health challenge among gastrointestinal malignancies, with limitations in the efficacy of existing single-treatment modalities. Andrographolide, a natural active component, has yet to have its radiosensitizing mechanisms fully elucidated. Objectives: This article was designed to elucidate Andrographolide’s synergistic inhibition with radiotherapy and its molecular basis on human esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (EC9706) cells. Methods: Using EC9706, cell proliferation was detected by the CCK-8 assay (at 24/48/72 h), migration ability was assessed by the scratch assay (at 12/24/48 h), radiosensitivity was analyzed by the colony formation (CF) assay (at 0-6 Gy), and the level of associated proteins was subjected to detection by Western blot (WB). Results: The combination group (DG) suggested the strongest proliferation inhibition at all time points [vs. control group (AG)], with the most visible distinction at 72 h. The scratch healing rate was the lowest (at 48 h vs. AG) (P < 0.01). As the radiation dose increased, the CF rate (CFR) declined markedly (6 Gy vs. AG, P < 0.001). Molecular detection revealed that the DG had the highest expression of Cleaved Caspase-3 and Bax, and the lowest expression of Bcl-2, NF-κB p65, and p-IκBα (P < 0.01). Conclusion: Andrographolide enhances the radiosensitivity of EC cells by activating apoptosis pathways and inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway, providing experimental evidence for clinical combined treatment.

title: Antioxidative effect of rhizome of Zinziber officinale on paraben induced lipid peroxidation: an in vitro study.
authors: Veena Asnani; Ramtej J. Verma
abstract: Antioxidative effect of aqueous extract of rhizome of Ginger (Zinziber officinale) was examined on p-hydroxybenzoic acid (paraben) induced lipid peroxidation. Addition of paraben (25-150 microg/mL) to liver and kidney homogenates significantly increases H2O2 induced lipid peroxidation in vitro. Effect was dose dependent up to 100 microg/mL concentration. An addition of aqueous extract of ginger significantly reduced paraben (100 microg/mL) induced lipid peroxidation in liver and kidney homogenates. The effect was concentration dependent.

title: Determination of diclofenac released from suppositories using UV spectrophotometry, spectra derivative spectrophotometry and HPLC.
authors: Małgorzata Sznitowska; Małgorzata Stokrocka
abstract: Spectrophotometric method is often recommended in dissolution testing of not only tablets or capsules but also suppositories. Dissolution rate of diclofenac sodium was studied using a pharmacopoeial flow-through apparatus and pH 7.3 buffer. For two lipophilic suppository bases (Witepsol W-32 and H-19) dissolution rate was overestimated with the spectrophotometric zero-order method in comparison to HPLC method, although the difference was statistically significant only in the case of the Witepsol W-32 basis. On the other hand, first derivative spectrophotometry allowed for elimination of the interference of the suppository lipophilic components dissolved in the buffer medium and no difference was observed between the results of this analysis in comparison with HPLC results.

title: Testing lyoequivalency for three commercially sustained-release tablets containing diltiazem hydrochloride.
authors: Hamzah A Maswadeh; Othman Al-Hanbali; Reem Kanaan; Ashok K. Shakya; Anwar Maraqa
abstract: In vitro release kinetics of three commercially available sustained release tablets (SR) diltiazem hydrochloride were studied at pH 1.1 for 2 h and for another 6 h at pH 6.8 using the USP dissolution apparatus with the paddle assemble. The kinetics of the dissolution process was studied by analyzing the dissolution data using five kinetic equations: the zero-order equation, the first-order equation, the Higuchi square root equation, the Hixson-Crowell cube root law and the Peppas equation. Analyses of the dissolution kinetic data for diltiazem hydrochloride commercial SR tablets showed that both Dilzacard and Dilzem SR tablets released drug by Non-Fickian (Anomalous transport) release with release exponent (n) equal to 0.59 and 0.54, respectively, which indicate the summation of both diffusion and dissolution controlled drug release. Bi-Tildiem SR tablets released drug by super case II (n = 1.29) which indicate zero-order release due to the dissolution of polymeric matrix and relaxation of the polymer chain. This finding was also in agreement with results obtained from application of zero-order and Hixson-Crowell equations. A dissolution profile comparative study was done to test the lyoequivelancy of the three products by using the mean dissolution time (MDT), dissimilarity factor f1 and similarity factor f2. Results showed that the three products are different and not lyoequivalent.

title: Application of thin-layer chromatography for the quality control and screening the free radical scavenging activity of selected pharmacuetical preparations containing Salvia officinalis L. extract.
authors: Łukasz Cieśla; Monika Waksmundzka‐Hajnos
abstract: Thin-layer chromatographic method, with postchromatographic derivatization, was applied for the purposes of the quality control of pharmaceutical preparations, containing S. officinalis L. extract. Six finished products underwent the analysis: capsules, tablets, two ointments, tincture and finished product being a mixture of ethanolic S. officinalis and Thymi vulgaris extracts. Chromatographic and free radical scavenging fingerprints, obtained for the herbal products, were compared with the profiles of the authenticated botanical reference material. The application of the proposed technique revealed most of the fingerprints, developed for the analyzed preparations, matched with the profiles obtained for authenticated plant material. The developed method was found suitable for the quality control of herbal preparations containing sage extract.

title: Safety of oral nifuroxazide – analysis of data from a spontaneous reporting system
authors: Katarzyna Karłowicz-Bodalska; Krystyna Głowacka; Kamila Boszkiewicz; Stanisław Han; Anna Wiela−Hojeńska
abstract: Nifuroxazide (4-hydroxy-benzoic acid; 2-[(5nitro-2-furanyl)methylene]hydrazide) is a chemotherapeutic agent belonging to the nitrofuran family.Indications for its use are acute and chronic bacterial diarrhea and other diseases with diarrhea (1).The drug has local antibacterial activity against some Gram-positive bacteria of the genus Staphylococcus and Gram-negative bacteria from the Enterobacteriaceae family: Yersinia spp., Escherichia spp., Enterobacter spp., Klebsiella spp.and Salmonella spp.It does not affect the bacteria Proteus vulgaris, Proteus mirabilis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (1-3).Recently, attention has been paid to its antitumor potential in neuroblastoma, multiple myeloma, colorectal and breast cancer, efficacy in the treatment of graft-versus-host disease and nephroprotection in diabetes (4-10).The exact mechanism of action of nifuroxazide has not yet been identified.It probably has an inhibitory effect on dehydrogenase activity and protein synthesis in bacterial cells.Aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) is responsible for the bioactivation of this prodrug.It has been found that nifuroxazide is a potent inhibitor of the Janus kinase 2 pathways and transcription factor 3 (JAK2/STAT3).It also has direct effects on oxidative stress and apoptosis (2,(4)(5)(6).Frequent self-administration of this drug by patients makes it necessary to pay attention to selfmedication, which in accordance with the guidelines of the World Health Organization is defined as ìusing medication by the consumer to treat signs/symptoms or minor health problems, recognized as such by themselvesî.In practice, this term also includes treatment by family members or friends, mainly, when the child is being treated (11).It should be responsible and safe, especially considering that diarrhea, in particular, acute diarrhea, is a serious problem of primary and hospital care.Itís serious complications, such as electrolyte disturbances, oligovolemic shock and even death, are dangerous especially for newborns, babies, small children and elderly people, due to their susceptibility to dehydration (12,13).The fact that adverse effects inevitably accompany the desired therapeutic effects

title: GC-MS Analysis and Biological activity of Essential Oil of Fruits, Needles and Bark of Pinus pinea grown wildly in Jordan
authors: Baha Halloum; Ashok K. Shakya; Zaha A. Elagbar; Rajashri R. Naik
abstract: Pinus pinea L. (Italian stone pine) belongs to the family Pinaceae which consists of 250 species of the plants.In recent classification P. halepensis, P. brutia, P. heldreichii, P. pinaster, P. pinea, P. canariensis, and P. roxburghii are grouped within the subsection of pinaster, also known as the Mediterranean pine group (1, 2).Pinus pinea is widely spread in the northern hemisphere, especially in the Mediterranean region, Europe, Asia, South Africa, and North and Central America (3).P. halepensis and P. brutia can be adopted in different environmental conditions.In Arab countries, it is usually located in the mountain regions of Lebanon, Syria, Algeria, Libya, and the Moroccan countryside.It is abundantly grown in Jordan reaching to a height of 30 m. Due to its medicinal properties, the essential oils of Pinus pinea have been used in folk medicine for the treatment of skin diseases such as eczema and psoriasis and as an analgesic and anti-inflammatory agent.The essential oil from the cones and needles of Pinus pinea showed significant wound healing activity and had a remarkable effect on rheumatic pain (4).Essential oils derived from Pinus pinea grown in Lebanon (5) showed cytotoxic activities against drug-sensitive CCRF/ADR5000 leukemia cells with IC 50 values ranging from 29.5 µg/mL to 61.4 µg/mL.The volatile composition of Pinus pinea L. needles (6) showed significant variation in the chemical constituents.Several studies have shown a significant difference in the volatile composition of the essential oil which may be due to the geographic location, climatic conditions, and time of collection.The variation in the chemical constituents may also affect its antioxidant activity.Scavengers like flavonoids, polyphenols, and phenolic acids are excellent antioxidant compounds that scavenge free radicals like peroxide and hydroperoxide, and thus inhibit the oxidative stress that causes diseases (7).

title: HPLC-DAD-ESI/MS Analysis of Arnica TM Constituents
authors: Katarzyna Kimel; Sylwia Godlewska; Mirosława Krauze‐Baranowska; Loretta Pobłocka‐Olech
abstract: The herbal drugs obtained from Arnica montana flowers are known for their anti-inflammatory activity.However, there is no detailed data on chemical constituents of the whole Arnica plant.HPLC-DAD-ESI/MS analysis of the whole Arnica montana plant (Arnica TM), used in the preparation of allopathic and homeopathic medicinal products, has been conducted.The qualitative and quantitative analysis comprised phenolic acids, flavonoids and sesquiterpene lactones ñ helenalin and dihydrohelenalin esters identified earlier in Arnica flowers.The analyzed material showed to be a rich source of caffeoylquinic acid (CQA) derivatives, especially 3,5di-O-caffeoylquinic acid.According to the literature data, the anti-inflammatory activity of extracts from the whole Arnica montana plant can be due to CQA presence as dominating compounds.

title: Impact of sterilisation conditions on the rheological properties of thermoresponsive pluronic F-127-based gels for the ophthalmic use
authors: Jakub Burak; Kamil P. Grela; Janusz Pluta; Bożena Karolewicz; Dominik Marciniak
abstract: Sterilisation is a key step in obtaining ophthalmic formulations, such as hydrogels, which ensure prolonged contact of the active substance with the cornea.In this research Pluronic F-127-based gels were sterilised with one from four proposed methods: steam-autoclaving at 121 O C for 20 min (S1) or at 105 O C for 30 min (S2), sterile filtration through membranes with 0.2 µm pore size (S3), or microwave-autoclaving (S4).Rheological properties of the gels after sterilisation were compared to those before sterilisation, and statistical analysis of viscosity, phase transition temperature, and temperature coefficient were conducted.Method S3 had the least impact on rheological properties of the hydrogels, however, it does not provide terminal sterilisation, and has many limitations in use.Steam-autoclaving has broader application spectrum.Temperature seems to be the crucial factor of the process, not the length of the procedure, that is why method S2 is preferred over S1.

title: Polyphenols action against oxidative stress formation in endothelial cells.
authors: Wojciech Łuczaj; Ewa Zapora; Marek Szczepański; Krzysztof Wnuczko; Elżbieta Skrzydlewska
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG), theaflavins (TFs) and black tea extract (BTE) on oxidative stress formation as well as on antioxidant system of human vein endothelial cells (HUVEC). HUVEC were incubated for 0,5 h with 100 mM tert-butyl hydroperoxide (t-BHP) for oxidative stress formation. The influence of EGCG, TFs, and BTE on oxidative stress and antioxidant system parameters was investigated by the pre-incubation for 2 h with 50 mg/mL of each compound. Half hour exposure to t-BHP caused statistically significant decrease in GSH-Px activity and in the content of GSH, vitamin A, vitamin E as well as tryptophan. Moreover, pretreatment of cells with t-BHP caused statistically significant increase in activities of Cu,Zn-SOD, GSSG-R and in the level of MDA and dityrosine. Pretreated with t-BHP endothelial cells, subjected to EGCG, TFs and black tea extract, are partially protected against oxidative activity of t-BHP causing statistically significant increase in GSH-Px activity, GSH and tryptophan level and decrease in MDA and dityrosine level in comparison with HUVEC pretreated with t-BHP group. These results indicate the beneficial effect of tea polyphenolic compounds on HUVEC antioxidant abilities and, in consequence, their protective effect in cell components.

title: DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF RP-HPLC METHOD FOR SIMULTANEOUS QUANTIFICATION OF SULFACETAMIDE SODIUM AND PREDNISOLONE SODIUM PHOSPHATE
authors: Nabiha Abdullah; Fizza Karamat; Shaista Qamar; Mateen Abbas; Abdulmuqeet Khan; Naseem Ullah
abstract: Sulfacetamide, a principal member of sulfonamide antibiotics, is a bacteriostatic agent.It is a benzenoid amino compound obtained from the parent molecule sulfanilic acid.It is responsible for competitive inhibition of bacterial enzyme dihydropteroate synthetase that causes the synthesis of para-aminobenzoic acid by fusion of pteridine with aminobenzoic acid, thereby restricting bacterial dihydrofolic acid formation and preventing bacterial cell multiplication (1).It is active against gram positive and gram negative bacteria.It is a potent, white, crystalline, synthetic drug; its sodium salt is used to treat conjunctivitis, blepharitis, trachoma, corneal ulcer and other ophthalmic pathological conditions (2-4).Chemically sulfacetamide sodium (SFS) (Fig. 1) is defined as Sodium acetyl[(4aminophenyl)sulphonyl]azanide having molecular weight 254.2 g/mol (5,6).Its ionization constant is 5.4 and biological half-life is 7 to 13 hours (7).Prednisolone sodium phosphate (PSP) (Fig. 2) is a glucocorticoid, a synthetic corticosteroid used for ocular anti-inflammatory therapy.It acts by

title: DEVELOPMENT AND IN-VITRO CHARACTERIZATION OF NANOEMULSION-BASED BUCCAL PATCHES OF VALSARTAN
authors: Rana Abu‐Huwaij; Rania Hamed; Enas Daoud; Ahlam Zaid Alkilani
abstract: Nanoemulsions (NEs) are isotropic mixtures of oils, surfactants, and co-surfactants that can be used as drug carriers.The typical droplet size falls from 20 ñ 200 nm (1).This nano-size provides a large surface area which increases the dissolution rate, thus the absorption and the bioavailability (2, 3).NEs are nontoxic and nonirritant, therefore, they are excellent candidates for drug delivery (4).They protect the drug from hydrolysis and oxidation due to encapsulation in oil-droplet (5).They enhance the permeation of a drug through the skin (4) as well as the blood-brain barrier (6).NEs are being investigated for the potential applications through the different routes of administration; transdermal (7), parenteral (8), ocular (9), oral (10), pulmonary (11), buccal (12) and nasal delivery (13).NEs are being engineered to overcome the different drug delivery barriers for each route of administration.The buccal route is becoming the most commonly used drug delivery as an alternative to the oral route.It offers unique advantages of ease accessibility, unidirectional drug flux, and hepatic first-pass metabolism bypass, that leads to bioavailability enhancement as well as patient compliance ( 14).Different dosage forms were used for buccal delivery such as gels (15), tablets (16), patches (17) and sprays (18).All formulations were employed to optimize the contact time of the formulation at the site of application in order to enhance drug penetration.Carbopol AE (CP) 971P is a well-known mucoadhesive polymer that optimizes the contact time of the formulation.It is a readily water-swellable polymer.It is used in a diverse range of pharmaceutical application to control drug release, adhere to the mucosal tissue in buccal, nasal, vaginal and rectal application, and thicken the topical gels, creams, and lotions to gain different viscosities and flow properties (19).

title: A Stability Indicating RP-HPLC Method Development for Simultaneous Estimation of Alogliptin, Pioglitazone, and Metformin in Finished Pharmaceutical Formulations
authors: Israa Habash; Ramadan Al‐Shdefat; Mohammad Hailat; Wael Abu Dayyih
abstract: Diabetes Mellitus (DM) is one of the significant metabolic issues inclining unfriendly wellbeing nowadays (1).One of the hallmarks of DM is the presence of hyperglycemia in individuals who suffer from DM (2).Hyperglycemia, in the long term, is a reason for damage for several organs, including the eyes, kidneys, nerves, and others (2).There are two subtypes of DM, DM type I (insulin-dependent DM) and type II (adult-onset DM) (3).At present, there are different treatments, both oral and injectable, available for the treatment of DM type II (4).The selection of suitable therapy for DM hyperglycemia is based on the pathophysiological stage of the progressive disease at the onset of the start of therapy (1).Alogliptin (Fig. 1) is a selective, orally bioavailable inhibitor of enzymatic activity of dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4).Alogliptin is a promising treatment for type II DM with a lower frequency of severe hypoglycemia (2).Pioglitazone (Fig. 1) is a Thiazolidinediones (TZDs).Pioglitazone exerts its action through its insulin-sensitizing effect that is usually used to treat DM of type II (3).The hypoglycemic effect of pioglitazone is believed to be through increasing the transactivation activity of Peroxisome Proliferators Activated Receptors (PPARs) (3).Metformin is a member of biguanides; biguanides consist of two guanidine attached to others (4).Metformin is used to lower glucose that is used orally.It is known since 1957 as a treatment for non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM).It is known about metformin that it has the capability of lowering blood glucose, but it does not lead to ANALYSIS

title: Exosomes and Their Application as Drug Delivery System in Cancer Therapy
authors: Kun Yang; BINGSUO MA; Ting Yu; K. Li; Liangming Zhang; Xingyi Yuan; HAIZHU ZHANG; Zijun Yan; Tong Chen
abstract: Exosomes are extracellular vesicles naturally released from cells. Exosomes from different sources play different roles in cellular component exchange, signal transduction, and pathological development. Exosomes have distinct biological characteristics such as low immunogenicity, easy uptake by cells, crossing the blood-brain barrier, natural targeting, and easy modification. Many studies show that exosomes as drug carriers have a great application prospect in cancer therapy. In this review, we review the biogenesis, origin, biological characteristics of exosomes, and the exosome drug delivery system and its application for cancer therapy are summarized to provide a reference for the study of exosomes.

title: g-C3N4-BASED PHOTOCATALYTIC MATERIALS: RECENT ENHANCEMENTS AND APPLICATIONS IN ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION
authors: Yuanjiao Feng; Hong Miao; Xue Zeng
abstract: In recent decades, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) a non-metallic semiconductor photocatalyst, has garnered significant attention due to its exceptional electronic configuration, remarkable visible light responsiveness, and unparalleled chemical stability, showcasing immense potential in environmental remediation. Nevertheless, the high recombination rate of photo-generated carriers and limited photocatalytic efficiency of a single g-C3N4 material limit its wide application. Therefore, constructing g-C3N4 based composite materials has become an efficient way to improve their photocatalytic effect. Here, we review the approaches for augmenting the photocatalytic performance of these composites, encompassing the rational architecture of their composite structures, the refinement of modification protocols, and an intensive examination of the underlying mechanisms that facilitate the photocatalytic efficacy improvement of g-C3N4. Furthermore, we discuss the advancements made in harnessing these composites for the efficient remediation of environmental pollutants. This provides ideas for further exploring new and efficient g-C3N4 based composites in the future, deepening our understanding of their photocatalytic mechanism, and expanding their applications in different fields.

title: Closely related isoxazoles may exhibit opposite immunological activities.
authors: Michał Zimecki; Marcin Mą̨czyński; Jolanta Artym; Stanisław Ryng

title: Fatty Acids Analysis and Antioxidant Activity of a Lipid Extract obtained from Mercurialis annua L. grown wildly in Jordan
authors: Nidhal A. Al-Douri; Ashok K. Shakya
abstract: Aerial parts of Mercurialis annua L. were used in the present study, and fatty acid content in lipid extract was determined using GC-FID.The major fatty acids identified were αñlinolenic acid (20.3%), heptadecanoic acid (12.8%), palmitic acid (11.9%), pentadecanoic acid (11.7%), cis-10-pentadecanoic acid (11.2%), linoleic acid (7.7%), tridecanoic Acid (4.6%), stearic (4.4%), cis-11,14-eicosadienoic acid (3.8%), beside of minor fatty acids (palmitoleic acid, cis-13,16-docosadienoic acid, arachidic acid, behenic acid, cis-10heptadecenoic acid and myristic acid).Antioxidant properties of the extract were determined via DPPH radical scavenging, β-carotene bleaching assay and NO radical scavenging assay.The extract produced significant antioxidant activity in-vitro.The data shown here may broaden our knowledge on composition and antioxidant activity of lipid constituents from Mercurialis annua L.

title: Influence of brassica sprouts on short chain fatty acids concentration in stools of rats with thyroid dysfunction
authors: Justyna Dobrowolska‐Iwanek; Paweł Zagrodzki; Ewelina Prochownik; Aneta Jarkiewicz; Paweł Paśko
abstract: The aim of the study was to investigate the influence of kohlrabi and broccoli sprouts added to the diet on the concentrations of short-chain fatty acids in feces samples of rats with thyroid dysfunction.Two models of hypothyroidism were used.The first one was based on the diet with iodine deficiency and the second by sulfadimethoxine addition to the animal drinking water.In most cases, the concentrations of acetic acid, propanoic acid and butanoic acid in stool samples obtained from rats with thyroid dysfunction were insignificantly lower than found in the control group.Moreover, almost in all cases the diet enriched with brassica sprouts insignificantly increased the concentration of fatty acids in investigated material.A significant positive correlation between concentrations of butanoic and acetic acids was found in different groups of rats.In conclusion, the addition of broccoli or kohlrabi sprouts in ratís diet may slightly alleviate the decline of concentrations of some fatty acids in the stool of animals with thyroid dysfunction.Long term effects of this phenomenon should be evaluated in future studies.

title: EVALUATION OF THE TOTAL FLAVONOID CONTENT AND ANTIMICROBIAL ACTIVITY OF THE TINCTURES OF PROPOLIS OF UKRAINIAN ORIGIN
authors: Nataliia Hudz; Oleksii Korytniuk; Oksana Yezerska; Olena I. Motyka; В. А. Туркіна; Raisa Korytniuk; Piotr Wieczorek
